case_name: Union of India v. Publisher of The Indian Observer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2097 of 1968 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2097 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 11, 1965 of the Delhi High Court in C.W. No. 197-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 11, 1965 of the Delhi High Court in C.W. No. 197-D of 1965.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 226 filed by the respondent was allowed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate from a judgement of the Punjab High Court by which the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution filed by the respondent was allowed

facts.text: Ban imposed on sale of The Indian Observer by licensees of Railway Book Stalls set aside by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and the ban imposed on the sale of a news weekly called The Indian Observer by the licensees of the Railway Book Stalls throughout the companyntry under directions issued by the appellant was set aside.

facts.text: Respondent is owner and publisher of weekly newspaper The Indian Observer with circulation approximately 1,35,000.

anchor.surface_text: According to the writ petition, the petitioner was the owner and publisher of a weekly newspaper known as The Indian Observer which had a wide sale in India, its weekly circulation being approximately 1,35,000 companyies.

facts.text: The Indian Observer sold at all railway stations managed by Railway Board till March 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Till March 1965 the .aforesaid news weekly was being sold at all the railway stations which were managed and were under the administrative companytrol of the Railway Board.

facts.text: The Indian Observer published constructive criticism on government departments including railways.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the policy of the news weekly was to publish a companystructive criticism and fair companyment in public interest on the working of different departments of the Government and to suggest remedial measures.,

facts.text: Issue of 11th September 1964 of The Indian Observer alleged black-marketing in deluxe train tickets by railway staff.

anchor.surface_text: In,some of the companyies of the news Weekly, certain matters regarding the maladministration of the Railway had been published. Reference was made in particular to the issue of 11th September, 1964 in which allegations were made about the black-marketing in deluxe train tickets.

facts.text: On 22nd September 1964, Circulation Manager of petitioner received letter from M/s Gulab Singh & P Ltd banning sale on Northern Railways book stalls.

anchor.surface_text: and on 22nd September, 1964, the Circulation Manager of the Petitioner companypany received a letter from M s Gulab Singh  P  Ltd., one of the licensees, of the Railway Board for sale of printed matters intimating that the Northern Railways administration had banned the sale, of The Indian Observer on the Railway Book Stalls.

facts.text: General Manager, Northern Railways gave temporary permission to sell subject to review and asked for 12 old issues.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, when the petitioner took up the matter with the authorities companycerned, the General Manager, Northern Railways, wrote to him informing him that temporary permission had been given to the railway companytractors of printed matters to sell the news weekly subject to proper review of that paper and final orders which would be given later.

facts.text: Letter dated 16th March 1965 informed petitioner that sale of The Indian Observer would not be permitted on railway stations.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the petitioner was informed by means of a letter dated the 16th March 1965 that the sale of the weekly The Indian Observer companyld number be permitted on the railway stations.

facts.text: Railway return denied that The Indian Observer was sold at railway stations by licensed contractors.

anchor.surface_text: In the return which was filed by the Joint Director, Traffic  General , Railway Board, it was number denied that the news weekly The Indian Observer was being sold at the, railway stations by the licensed companytractors.

facts.text: Railway claimed The Indian Observer published sexy and obscene literature of low taste.

anchor.surface_text: It was asserted that the petitioner had been publishing sexy and obscene literature Lind the licensees had been raising objections on this score. The articles published in the Pews weekly were companysidered to be of low taste,

facts.text: Railway denied allegations of corruption and maladministration in railways published in The Indian Observer.

anchor.surface_text: The allegations made in the petition about the statements relating to companyruption and maladministration in the Railways which had been published in some of the issues of the news weekly was number denied.

facts.text: High Court quashed the ban on discriminatory grounds and lack of authority under clause 742.

anchor.surface_text: As the Railway Board was number authorised to exclude any publication from sale- on its own determination that it was obscene, it was held that the order which was made by that Board was without authority. The ban had hit the writ petitioner who had been made the object of discriminatory treatment.

facts.text: Book stalls on railway platforms belong to licensees who have agreement with President of India.

anchor.surface_text: The book- stalls on the railway platforms where books, manazines and newsp- apers are sold, belong to the licencees who have entered into an agreement with the President of India.

facts.text: Licence agreements allow Railway to prohibit sale of obscene or scurrilous publications.

anchor.surface_text: Under clause 5 the licensor had the right of prohibiting the sale, or exhibition of any publication of an obscene or scurrilous nature and of any publication to which good, sufficient, and reasonable objections companyld be shown and the decision of the licensor was to be final and binding oil the licensee.

facts.text: Clause 742 of Indian Railway Code bans sale of obscene books and publications prohibited by Government.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 742 to the extent it is material is reproduced below - The sale of obscene books and pictures and publications prohibited by the Government should be strictly banned.

facts.text: Railway Board letter dated March 26, 1965 instructed to stop sale of Indian Observer due to low taste bordering on obscenity.

anchor.surface_text: In the letter of the Railway Board dated March 26, 1965 it was stated that it had companye to the Boards, numberice that the Indian Observer generally companytained articles written in very low taste bordering oh obscenity.

facts.text: Indian Observer sold on railway platforms since 1963.

anchor.surface_text: news weekly inquestion had been sold on railway platforms since 1963 number wasit suggested that the Railway Board had ever accorded individual sanction for the sale of every single book and publication

facts.text: Supreme Court held ban discriminatory under Art 14.

anchor.surface_text: We companycur with the view of the High Court that the impugned order of the Railway Board was discriminatory. No proper or valid grounds have been shown for sustaining the discrimination made.

facts.text: Railway platforms accessible to bona fide travellers and public with platform ticket.

anchor.surface_text: Railway platforms may be the property  1 .1969 3 S.C.R. 548. of the railways, but it cannot be disputed that every bona fide traveller or every other member of the public who, buys a platform ticket can have access to the railway platforms.

facts.text: Certificate for appeal granted by High Court on July 7, 1968.

issues.text: Whether the Railway Board was authorised to impose a ban on the sale of the news weekly on its own determination that it was obscene without it being previously prohibited by the Government under Clause 742 of the Indian Railway Code

anchor.surface_text: Before, the High Court, s. 28 of the Indian Railways Act 1890, hereinafter called the Act, and the relevant sub-clauses of clause 742 of the Indian Railway Code were pressed into service for challenging the ban which had been imposed on the sale of the news weekly. The High Court was of the view that the petitioner before it had cited and produced instances of publications which were freely on sale on the bookstalls on the railway platforms to show that the material which was sought to be excluded or  grounds on obscenity, was hardly distinguishable from the other popular magazines of foreign and Indian origin. Reliance was placed on the provisions of clause 742 of the Indian Railway Code which established that a publication to attract the ban imposed by the Railway Board must have been previously prohibited by the Government. As the Railway Board was number authorised to exclude any publication from sale- on its own determination that it was obscene, it was held that the order which was made by that Board was without authority.

issues.text: Whether the ban imposed on the sale of The Indian Observer amounted to discriminatory treatment violating Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court and before us the main companylaint of the present respondent is based On an infraction of Article 14 of the Constitution and it has been asserted that the news weekly Indian Observer was singled out for discriminatory treatment inasmuch as publications companytaining similar material were number prohibited from sale by the Railway Board on the book-stalls at the platforms and in the trains etc.

issues.text: The question that has next to be resolved is whether Art. 14 could be invoked by the respondent in the present case

anchor.surface_text: It is thus apparent that the High Court was fully justified in taking the view that the Indian Observer had been sin-led out for being banned and this clearly amounted to a discriminatory,treatment. The question that has next to be resolved is whether Art. 14 could be invoked by the respondent in the present case. It has number been and indeed cannot be disputed that the Railway Board will fall within the definition of State as given in Art. 12 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the respondent could take advantage of the provisions of s. 28 of the Indian Railways Act

anchor.surface_text: A certain amount of discussion took place before us with regard to the applicability of s. 28 of the Act which companytains pro- hibition against under preference being shown by the Railway Administration in any respect whatsoever. Tn the view that we have taken about the applicability of Art. 14 we do number companysider it necessary to decide whether the respondent companyld take advan- tage of the provisions of that section.

holdings.text: The impugned order of the Railway Board was discriminatory violating Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We concur with the view of the High Court that the impugned order of the Railway Board was discriminatory. No proper or valid grounds have been shown for sustaining the discrimination made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Indian Observer singled out for ban while publications with similar material freely sold; no valid grounds shown; High Court finding concurred with.

holdings.text: Railway Board not authorised under Clause 742 to impose ban on publication based on its own determination of obscenity; requires prior prohibition by the Government.

anchor.surface_text: Now in the Indian Railway Code the policy or the principle laid down in categorical terms in sub-clause viii of Clause 742 is that the contractor should provide equal opportunity to all the popular newspapers for sale in their stalls on the same terms. This was subject to certain conditions, one of which was that the sale of obscene books and pictures and publications prohibited by the Government should be strictly banned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 742 mandates ban only for obscene books or govt-prohibited publications; Railway Board letter cites low taste/obscenity but no govt prohibition shown; 'Government' not equated to Railway Board.

holdings.text: The respondent publisher can invoke Article 14 to challenge the discriminatory administrative order of the Railway Board.

anchor.surface_text: The administrative act or order of the Railway Board can, therefore, be challenged under Art. 14. The respondent is not asking for the enforcement of any such fundamental right as would come within the rule laid down in the previous decision of this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Railway Board is 'State' under Art 12; publisher challenges directive to licensees discriminating among popular newspapers without legal basis; platforms open to public.

holdings.text: Publisher has locus standi under Art 226 to challenge Railway Board's discriminatory ban order as violative of Art 14.

anchor.surface_text: If that order is discriminatory and, cannot be justified on anyof the well known grounds. the respondent can challenge it in a Petition under Art.226 of the Constitution as violative of Art.14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not claiming right to use premises but equality in sale via licensees; distinguishes cases on property rights/meetings as platforms public and directive discriminatory.

holdings.text: Railway Board v. Niranjan Singh not applicable as railway platforms are accessible to bona fide travellers and public unlike internal premises.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to appreciate how the ratio of that decision could be applied to the present case. The meetings of workers which had taken place there had been held inside workshops, stores and depots and within office compounds, Railway platforms may be the property of the railways, but it cannot be disputed that every bona fide traveller or every other member of the public who, buys a platform ticket can have access to the railway platforms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent involved internal govt premises for meetings; here public access to platforms and issue is discriminatory ban on publication sale via licensees.

holdings.text: Not necessary to decide whether respondent could invoke s.28 of Indian Railways Act given Art 14 applicability.

anchor.surface_text: Tn the view that we have taken about the applicability of Art. 14 we do not consider it necessary to decide whether the respondent could take advantage of the provisions of that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 14 sufficient to resolve; prohibition against under-preference not addressed on merits.

holdings.text: High Court certificate for appeal not vitiated despite critical observations on prior judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Although such an order will not per se vitiate the certificate, both judicial propriety and decorum demand that a Bench while considering the question of granting certificate for appeal to this Court ought not to be critical of or express any dissent from the judgment appealed against

holdings.reasoning_summary: Does not per se invalidate; concerns judicial propriety but constitutional requirements satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: We concur with the view of the High Court that the impugned order of the Railway Board was discriminatory. No proper or valid grounds have been shown for sustaining the discrimination made. A certain amount of discussion took place before us with regard to the applicability of s. 28 of the Act which contains pro- hibition against under preference being shown by the Railway Administration in any respect whatsoever.

anchor.surface_text: Now in the Indian Railway Code the policy or the principle laid down in categorical terms in sub-clause viii of Clause 742 is that the contractor should provide equal opportunity to all the popular newspapers for sale in their stalls on the same terms. This was subject to certain conditions, one of which was that the sale of obscene books and pictures and publications prohibited by the Government should be strictly banned.

We concur with the view of the High Court that the impugned order of the Railway Board was discriminatory. No proper or valid grounds have been shown for sustaining the discrimination made. A certain amount of discussion took place before us with regard to the applicability of s. 28 of the Act which contains pro- hibition against under preference being shown by the Railway Administration in any respect whatsoever.
